utterances: I was here for the 2002 bloom.
And, you know, I'm not one of those people who's jaded.
Yeah, give us a sense where there is all kinds of awful, how would you describe this one?
Well it tends to bloom in pulses, so it doesn't make the same smell all the time.
And when it's at its worst it does smell like a dead animal.
The rest of the time for me - it smelled like what I thought was rotten milk.
An old milk carton in an elementary school playground in August, in the trash can, you know.
But why, just to take this to a more scientific level - why would a plant, I mean, what's the thinking here that says that a flowering plant would have a stench like this in terms of survival value.
Well, you know, a lot of plants have smells.
And they're generally to attract pollinators and this plant is no different.
But instead of attracting butterflies or hummingbirds, it wants to attract carrion beetles and sweat flies and flesh flies.
So, different smell for different, you know.
How is your supply of carrion beetles and sweat flies in Pasadena - or San Marino, and did the local horticulturalists know you have them?
Well, I have a feeling we'll find out soon.
When we have other carrion smelling flowers, houseflies come and lay their eggs on them.
Because they think it's decaying flesh.
So, they lay their eggs on there and then they hatch it and then we've maggots.
And I'm going to meet Whoopi, and I'm going to be so happy.
And then I'm going to have the bestest of dreams (laughter).
Is there a countdown clock or you do have a Webcam.
How are we going to see?
I'm happy to say I'll be back in California next week.
So, I guess there's a chance I'll have a viewing.
Nobody - there haven't been so many bloomed in captivity so to speak that we can predict the bloom cycle that clearly.
I thought it was getting close because the growth rate had slowed down…
…from five inches to 2.75 to half an inch a day.
But this morning it was four and a half inches taller.
So, it's going through another spurt.
We were guessing Monday or Tuesday, although it hasn't started coloring up yet.
Let's talk one quick call before we have to change topics here and go to Tye(ph) in Washington, D.C.
And I was just wondering if this flower is at all related to the Rafflesia flower.
It has a similar pollination syndrome.
But they're not related, they're both from Sumatra.
All right thanks may be you can - oh, go ahead…
Oh, the Rafflesia is actually the largest single flower in the world.
Do you have one of those too?
No, they're very difficult to cultivate, it's a parasite on a vine.
…that we can't even grow the vine let alone get it and inoculate it with the parasite.
It is something to look forward to.
